channel.title: Possible answer to how the universe began
channel.description:
I just thought of something...
Maybe it never did. Think about it. Theoretically, there is no end or begining to the universe(space), which could possibly mean that time never began...
Just as our minds can barely handle that there is no end to space, maybe it is the same to time... like... everything was aways here... period.

item.title: Possible answer to how the universe began
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

define: god

Genesis 1:1. In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth.

thats god, a being which is captable of creating everything, who keeps the whole world in place, and equally, he listens to individual people’s prayers,
he is capable of infinate things

i like the infinate part, it allows you to screw over thiests with mathematics,
eg. If god is infinatly powerful, can he create something more powerful then himself

item.title: Possible answer to how the universe began
item.dc:creator: @technik733 technik733
item.description:
@technik733 wrote:

Ok. I’d love to. But seriously you can’t argue about something when it’s not clear what the definition of the concept you’re arguing about is. And while you’re at it, define “Universe” because if the universe is everything that exists, nothing could have existed before it, which is logically flawed because logically something had to start the chain of events that produced the universe that exists in its current form.

Read full topic
item.source: Possible answer to how the universe began

item.title: Possible answer to how the universe began
item.dc:creator: @ThAt0n36Uy Elijah
item.description:
@ThAt0n36Uy wrote:

[quote=“technik733, post:69, topic:196851”]You guys have been bickering about whether or not “God” exists and whether he created the universe, but no one has taken the time to even define “God.”

Do you mean a perfect being? Do you mean it strictly as is said in the bible? Do you mean the highest form of consciousness? All knowing, all powerful, all loving? Come on, give me some specific definition so I can blow it out of the water. XP

I think it’s a possibly that the universe is cyclic, and at any one time there is an “anti-universe” evolving positrons and such that don’t naturally occur in our universe and as such is imperceptible to us. Every few billion years or so, the larger of the two begins collapsing and the smaller begins expanding until they effectively switch roles and it goes back the other way. I have absolutely no basis for any of this, but I just like this theory.[/quote]

Go live in solitude.

Read full topic
item.source: Possible answer to how the universe began

item.title: Possible answer to how the universe began
item.dc:creator: @technik733 technik733
item.description:
@technik733 wrote:

You guys have been bickering about whether or not “God” exists and whether he created the universe, but no one has taken the time to even define “God.”

Do you mean a perfect being? Do you mean it strictly as is said in the bible? Do you mean the highest form of consciousness? All knowing, all powerful, all loving? Come on, give me some specific definition so I can blow it out of the water. XP

I think it’s a possibly that the universe is cyclic, and at any one time there is an “anti-universe” evolving positrons and such that don’t naturally occur in our universe and as such is imperceptible to us. Every few billion years or so, the larger of the two begins collapsing and the smaller begins expanding until they effectively switch roles and it goes back the other way. I have absolutely no basis for any of this, but I just like this theory.

Read full topic
item.source: Possible answer to how the universe began

item.title: Possible answer to how the universe began
item.dc:creator: @ThatOneServer Mike_
item.description:
@ThatOneServer wrote:

Hiaburi:

I do believe the currently held theory that the universe did originate from a big bang, but I also believe that it has happened countless times before, that is another one of the theories at least, like the universe is expanding, there are 3 possibilities, it stops, it keeps on forever, it stops then reverses, un bib bang lol. Then another theory about the universe is that there are multiple universes, and once in a great while they collide, destroying both, and starting from scratch. The thing with all of this is if you try to figure it out it just raises more and more and more questions. I tend to stay away from these conversations…

In my opinion its impossible for there to be more than one universe.

The universe is a general word for what holds everything in existance.

Read full topic
item.source: Possible answer to how the universe began

item.title: Possible answer to how the universe began
item.dc:creator: @I_Br3ndan_I I Br3ndan I
item.description:
@I_Br3ndan_I wrote:

Oh btw, anyone who’s not British here might not have seen a program that was on a while ago on the telly. It was about 2 planets scientists have found which is close to us, and they may be habitable. Both of them rotate around their sun, like Earth rotates around the sun here, except they don’t rotate themselves like Earth does (No day, no night). One side is completely dark and freezing cold, and the other is extremely light and boiling hot. It may be too cold to live on, but, if the greenhouse effect has taken place, it may just be at the right temperature for us to settle down (On the cold side).

I can’t remember about the other one, I think that one was too close to the sun, but the cold side just might be cold enough for us to survive.

Read full topic
item.source: Possible answer to how the universe began

item.title: Possible answer to how the universe began
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Thabest:

Everything is just to fragile. I don’t believe in the big bang. The sun that keeps our planet warm for humans to live on, but not to warm, and not to cold. Everything in the human body is so perfectly aligned and fragile. I just don’t think it all could of happened by accident. I think there is some kind of higher force watching it. Not necessarily god, but some kind of higher force.

It’s a matter of evolution.

And Hiaburi, I find the idea of multiple universes very unlikely.

Read full topic

item.description:
@ninja_nub wrote:

How is the sun fragile? It’s basically a nuclear fusion factory. Please don’t say a nuclear fusion factory would be fragile… It’s really powerful.

Plus the amount of energy the sun gives off is enormous. It sends all of those magnetic rays that are powerful enough to fuck with earths power grid. Related to that, the nuclear flares given off are likes thousand if not millions of nuclear bombs going off at once.

item.source: Possible answer to how the universe began

item.title: Possible answer to how the universe began
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

I Br3ndan I:

I’ll need to read the Bible sometime. I really don’t know much about God (I’m a Christian… barely), and as I age, I become more and more intrigued by it.

I think non-Christians should read through the Bible as well so they can back up their arguments with scripture.

I Br3ndan I:

I seem to believe that ‘God’ was of another race; much more superior to us humans on Earth; from a different planet/area in our/other galaxies. It really is the most plausible explanation I can come up with. Can anyone (xxlegitxx, more specifically) tell me if it’s wrong to think such things about God?

I personally don’t see anything wrong with that. For all we know, we could be an ant farm for some higher being.

[quote=“I Br3ndan I, post:56, topic:196851”]All of those who are arguing against Catholicism and the existence of God: why are you doing it? If you do not believe in God, then that’s your business, it’s your loss. It’s a great faith. It exclaims love for one another and opposes everything evil.

What’s bad about it?

Edit: Apologies for the long post- I know they’re irritating to read.[/quote]

I personally am against Catholicism myself, because I think there are a lot of useless rituals involved, but anyway. The reason atheists detest Christianity is not because of the theory behind it, but because of the way it has been applied. Such as the Crusades, etc.

yakman:

i mean, come on, catholic-christianity and orthadox-christianity are barely distinguishable.

There are many key differences between Catholicism and Protestantism.

Read full topic
item.source: Possible answer to how the universe began

item.title: Possible answer to how the universe began
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

I Br3ndan I:

All of those who are arguing against Catholicism and the existence of God: why are you doing it? If you do not believe in God, then that’s your business

the reason is:
atheists cannot simply ignore theists anymore then homosexuals can ignore straight people
we have to understand religion to understand things like the Northern Ireland Troubles, Isreal-Palastine, and why there was just a suicide bomber in our towns.

in my own country, there was a war between catholic-christians and orthadox-christians. it was a fairly typical war, a lot of people died, of all beliefs, ect ect
but in the 40 years before that, when everyone was “officially” atheist, there was total peace and prosperity between everyone. After the fall of socialism, religious people started killing each other.

i mean, come on, catholic-christianity and orthadox-christianity are barely distinguishable.

in answer to your question, atheists have to take religion into account, we have no choice, and we don’t the way we have to, we would much prefer if there was no religion. So we debate against it.

the world would be a much nicer place if everyone kept their beliefs, or lack of them, to themselves.

Read full topic

item.source: Possible answer to how the universe began

item.title: Possible answer to how the universe began
item.dc:creator: @I_Br3ndan_I I Br3ndan I
item.description:
@I_Br3ndan_I wrote:

I’ll need to read the Bible sometime. I really don’t know much about God (I’m a Christian… barely), and as I age, I become more and more intrigued by it.

I seem to believe that ‘God’ was of another race; much more superior to us humans on Earth; from a different planet/area in our/other galaxies. It really is the most plausible explanation I can come up with. Can anyone (xxlegitxx, more specifically) tell me if it’s wrong to think such things about God?

I mean, if God isn’t from another planet, then he must have sent his son Jesus to Earth. I just can’t believe that the people who wrote the Bible were so intelligent. It’s written with hidden messages and morals riddled throughout, is it not? Jesus didn’t explain to them how to write like that… And I’m pretty damn sure you couldn’t have got an education at that time that was really advanced like that. Am I over exaggerating a little? Maybe I am; maybe it wasn’t written as well as I say it was.

But then again, maybe God gave the people who wrote the Bible the gift of writing, and great intelligence. Who knows. It’s hard to make ends meet.

I just can’t believe it. It’s not too hard to comprehend- it’s just that, as a human, I’m a totally stupid little shit, and I’m arrogant, too. In this society, it’s extremely hard to believe in God. I can overcome it sometimes, but most of the time, my social life interrupts with my belief in God.

All of those who are arguing against Catholicism and the existence of God: why are you doing it? If you do not believe in God, then that’s your business, it’s your loss. It’s a great faith. It exclaims love for one another and opposes everything evil.

What’s bad about it?

Edit: Apologies for the long post- I know they’re irritating to read.

Read full topic
item.source: Possible answer to how the universe began

Watch the christians say god made those scientists invent that.
[/quote]
If you want to be ignorant, keep saying things like that. If you haven’t noticed, I’m debating with logic, things that can be backed up with evidence, not with fanciful statements like, “God made scientists invent all those wonderful things.”[/quote]

I wasn’t directly pointing at you, but really, all the christians in my class (quite a few actually, and they aren’t stupid either, I go to the second highest form of education in my country so they should have at least some brains) say that God made scientists invent stuff.

Oh and about those third world people, most of them believe in some strange god, not in the christian god.

item.title: Possible answer to how the universe began
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

Silver Lining:

The Bible says seven days, not some unspecified amount of time. You mold the time specifications to allow for science, but Genesis is just too damn specific. When it says day, it means day. When it says the first bitch came from the first man, it means God ripped out Adam’s rib and called it “Eve”, not “God created a female to coexist with the male, and the offspring of the two’s offspring evolved over the next near-eternity, eventually creating a human male and female”. No room for loose interpretation.

en.wikipedia.org

Day-age creationism

Day-age creationism, a type of old Earth creationism, is an interpretation of the creation accounts in Genesis. It holds that the six days referred to in the Genesis account of creation are not ordinary 24-hour days, but are much longer periods (from thousands to billions of years). The Genesis account is then reconciled with the age of the Earth. Proponents of the day-age theory can be found among both theistic evolutionists, who accept the scientific consensus on evolution, and progressive crea...

yakman:

because the bible says so, 7 days is what it took

en.wikipedia.org

Day-age creationism

Day-age creationism, a type of old Earth creationism, is an interpretation of the creation accounts in Genesis. It holds that the six days referred to in the Genesis account of creation are not ordinary 24-hour days, but are much longer periods (from thousands to billions of years). The Genesis account is then reconciled with the age of the Earth. Proponents of the day-age theory can be found among both theistic evolutionists, who accept the scientific consensus on evolution, and progressive crea...

[quote=“yakman, post:50, topic:196851”]if you want to attribute those things to anyone, credit the scientists, engineers and mathematicans.
they created a way to get a lot of food easily so you can never be hungry.
they created a way to clean water, so you can never be thirsty, and wont die from cholera.
they created medicine, so you wont die from flu.

god and religion has given you nothing, except death, suffering and ignorance.
science and engineering has given you a lot of things.
god is obsolete, behold science, the new god.[/quote]

Too bad people from third world countries are hungry, thirsty, and dying from flu. If life is all we have to live for, it gives their existence absolutely no meaning. And that’s where the Bible comes in. It gives promise to those who have nothing in this world, promising them a better existence after death.

And God and religion used in the wrong context has ended in death, suffering, and ignorance.
And science used in the wrong context has also ended up in death, suffering, and ignorance.

Next time you use gross generalizations, at least make sure it is only applicable to religion.

Science can only prove things to a point.

R.I.P RSC:

Watch the christians say god made those scientists invent that.

If you want to be ignorant, keep saying things like that. If you haven’t noticed, I’m debating with logic, things that can be backed up with evidence, not with fanciful statements like, “God made scientists invent all those wonderful things.”

Read full topic

yakman:

[quote author=ThAt0n36Uy link=topic=261506.msg2173505#msg2173505 date=1207732418]How can you even sit there and say God needed time to create things.

because the bible says so, 7 days is what it took

he didnt create you, your dad created you when his condom broke

if you want to attribute those things to anyone, credit the scientists, engineers and mathematicans.
they created a way to get a lot of food easily so you can never be hungry.
they created a way to clean water, so you can never be thirsty, and wont die from cholera.
they created medicine, so you wont die from flu.

god and religion has given you nothing, except death, suffering and ignorance.
science and engineering has given you a lot of things.
god is obsolete, behold science, the new god.[/quote]

Watch the christians say god made those scientists invent that.

item.title: Possible answer to how the universe began
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“Silver Lining, post:49, topic:196851”][quote author=bowserjr2 link=topic=261506.msg2172341#msg2172341 date=1207707514]

so why did he save the man who was willing to give up his daughters?
did he die? no he didnt

God did not condone his actions. In fact, if you read a bit more, it was obvious that Lot was a bad example. My understanding is that he saved Lot because he was related to Abraham, with whom He made His covenant.

what I’m trying to say here is, no Christian copies that part of the bible, but they still copy the “moral” parts,
basically, my point is, the bible isn’t necessary for learning morality

Well I guess the Bible is assuming that the reader is not near retarded.

you know when one days passes into the next
time is change, if time doesn’t move, nothing will change

All I said was that your comparison between time and water was null. Nothing more. Furthermore, the Bible uses the word “day” to describe the first seven days. Show me where it says those days were 86 400 seconds as it is today. The rotation of the earth in the first millenia of creation was most definitely not the same as it is now.

Day does not mean like the day we have today, it can be period that was In all from millions to milliards of years.

[/quote]The Bible says seven days, not some unspecified amount of time. You mold the time specifications to allow for science, but Genesis is just too damn specific. When it says day, it means day. When it says the first bitch came from the first man, it means God ripped out Adam’s rib and called it “Eve”, not “God created a female to coexist with the male, and the offspring of the two’s offspring evolved over the next near-eternity, eventually creating a human male and female”. No room for loose interpretation.[/quote]
Yes I know that bible say 7 days, but like some said, Genesis 1 can be figurative and not literal.
Genesis 1 is proved that is not literal, since the science have an other explanation.

Maybe that say that he (God) made the world in 7 days was an easy way to say that he made a big mass into the center of Universe, make it explode (Big Bang), made the physic rules, make all the Atoms and molecule and how they react and made some sort of life on earth. (After that I know the Scientist have not found a way to create life of that so was on the earth before life.)
And then do small fixes on the living things in a long long time so they created many sort of Animals, bird, fish and the Humans we see today.

Read full topic
